<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/18/fed-report-shows-200k-additional-business-closures-covid?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Small Businesses Shake It Off
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/18/fed-report-shows-200k-additional-business-closures-covid" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Small businesses in a row" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMTkyL3NtYWxsX2J1c2luZXNzZXNfaW5fYV9yb3cuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">One year ago, just weeks into lockdowns and stay-at-home orders, economists warned of the potential closures of millions of businesses across the country. But preliminary data from the first 12 months of the pandemic shows those predictions fell flatter than our bet on skinny jeans never going out of style. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Fewer than 200,000 business establishments <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19s-toll-on-u-s-business-200-000-extra-closures-in-pandemics-first-year-11618580619?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">closed</a> from March 2020 to February 2021 on top of the roughly 600,000 businesses that typically turnover in a given year, according to a new Federal Reserve report. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Important distinction:</strong></span><span> An estimated 130,000 of those "excess" closures were businesses going under (as opposed to just closing one of their locations).</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Unsurprisingly, personal services were the hardest hit—about half of the excess failures were businesses like barber shops and nail salons. But some categories, including carry-out restaurants, grocery stores, and outdoor recreation, saw fewer failures than a normal year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> 200,000 excess closures certainly had devastating consequences for owners and employees, but the unemployment impact was <a href="https://www.reuters.com/business/pandemic-destroyed-fewer-us-firms-than-feared-fed-study-shows-2021-04-16/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">less than you might expect</a>. Business exits are typically higher among firms with five or fewer workers, and the majority of the US' 26 million small businesses are sole proprietorships. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">But this isn't over </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The full scope of business damage won't be known for years, and surveys continue to show many are still struggling under burdens of unpaid loans and back rent. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The impact of closures also hasn't been felt evenly, Fed surveys show. Firms owned by people of color <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/16/success/minority-owned-small-businesses-pandemic/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">experienced</a> larger declines in sales and more difficulty accessing capital. If requests for pandemic aid were granted, they were less likely than white-owned businesses to get the amount requested. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>The Fed report offers an upbeat view of business resiliency during Covid and evidence that PPP and other aid programs prevented more permanent damage. "Not only are things less bad than we thought, but they are less bad by an order of magnitude," MIT Sloan Prof. Scott Stern told the WSJ.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPORTS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/18/twelve-elite-european-soccer-clubs-try-form-super-league?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
European Soccer's Civil War
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/18/twelve-elite-european-soccer-clubs-try-form-super-league" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="TURIN, ITALY - SEPTEMBER 16:  Cristiano Ronaldo of Juventus FC celebrate..." style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80NzY5L2p1dmVudHVzX3ZfdXNfc2Fzc3VvbG9fLS5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Emilio Andreoli/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, a group of 12 elite European soccer clubs unveiled a <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/18/sports/soccer/super-league-united-liverpool-juventus-madrid.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">breakaway competition</a> called the Super League, a plan that could lead to the biggest shakeup in the sport since Zlatan Ibrahimović brought back the man bun.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Who's in?</strong> To start, <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/europe-top-soccer-clubs-super-league-11618773385?mod=hp_lead_pos11&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">six clubs</a> from England's Premier League, including Liverpool and Manchester United, and six more from Spain and Italy. The ultimate goal is to have 15 permanent teams in a "closed" structure more in line with US sports leagues.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">And what do they want? </strong>More money. Super League teams would get $400+ million each just for participating, a sum more than 4x what they'd earn from winning the current top European competition, the Champions League. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The response from existing soccer leadership: </strong>Imagine an announcer saying the word "goooooal" for 30 seconds, but replace that with "nooooo." UEFA, European soccer's governing body and the organization that runs the Champions League, called it a "cynical project," and even UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and French President Emmanuel Macron denounced it. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>a battle royale for the soul of European soccer. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/18/us-china-put-joint-statement-climate?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Friends With Climate Benefits
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="GIF of high fiving" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=402 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/Ymr4ufcSAtJ4Y/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="GIF of high fiving" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/Ymr4ufcSAtJ4Y/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The US and China don't agree on much—trade, aggressions in the South China Sea, where to set the thermostat. But in a <a href="https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-climate-shanghai-climate-change-john-kerry-905125d79b6c31940b8747df86c2a87a?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">joint statement</a> Saturday, the world's two largest economies said they'd work together to combat climate change. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you're looking for specifics, this is not the statement for you. But the countries did agree to take "<a href="https://www.ft.com/content/71f724ff-a25c-4ff7-8713-b0aa02d3adb5?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">concrete actions</a>" this decade to reduce emissions in line with the goals of the Paris Agreement, which commits countries to limit warming to "well below" two degrees Celsius relative to the preindustrial era.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>That won't happen </span><span><a href="https://www.axios.com/us-china-agree-joint-climate-action-838a35b5-92a8-47c6-901f-1a7e9926f5bc.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">without buy-in</a></span><span> from the US and China. The countries are No. 1 and No. 2 on the World's Top Emitters list, together contributing almost half of the fossil fuel emissions that warm the planet. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Compared to his predecessor, President Biden is taking a U-turn with an aggressive plan to tackle climate change. However, he has largely maintained the same antagonistic tone toward the Chinese government.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>later this week, the US will announce new carbon emissions targets before hosting 40 world leaders at a virtual climate summit. Chinese President Xi Jinping is a "maybe." </p>

<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Apparently things are looking up out there—hey we read this newsletter too. So it seems like in the not-too-distant future we’ll be able to walk outside or maybe even take a trip.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FITNESS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/04/18/safety-agency-warns-pelotons-treadmill-small-children-pets?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Safety Agency Tells Peloton Users to Look Before You Run
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Peloton is in a war of words with US regulators over the safety of one of its core products.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">On Saturday, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said customers of Peloton's Tread+ treadmill should <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/17/us-cpsc-tells-consumers-to-stop-using-pelotons-tread-treadmill.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">not use it</a> around small children or pets because they could get trapped underneath the machine.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The agency cited </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-treadmills-unsafe-for-people-with-young-children-or-pets-federal-agency-says-11618680690?mod=hp_lead_pos5&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">39 incidents</a></span><span> involving the Tread+, including the death of a child that Peloton acknowledged last month. </span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It's not clear whether Peloton's treadmill is more dangerous than other treadmills.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The company <a href="https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/peloton-refutes-consumer-product-safety-commission-claims-301270942.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pushed back</a> against the report, calling it "inaccurate and misleading." Peloton said there is "no reason to stop using the Tread+, as long as all warnings and safety instructions are followed." </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Peloton's biggest problem last year was making enough equipment to fulfill elevated demand for its connected fitness products. But 2021 has gone much differently—its stock price has fallen more than 20% and it's drawing the unwanted attention of regulators. </p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote:</strong> "Our patient could die at any moment."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Doctors for Russian dissident Alexei Navalny, who is 20 days into a hunger strike in Russian prison, say he <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/kremlin-critic-alexei-navalny-s-life-balance-aide-says-he-n1264424?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">could die</a> within days if he does not receive medical treatment. <p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Vaccines: </strong>Dr. Fauci said a <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/dr-fauci-expects-decision-jj-vaccine-soon-friday-2021-04-18/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">decision</a> on resuming J&J's paused Covid-19 vaccine will come by Friday. He told <em>Face the Nation</em> that he wouldn't be surprised if there were a "resumption in some form."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Earnings: </strong>Close your eyes and picture the most prototypical companies in "Corporate America"—those are the ones <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/16/investors-look-for-hints-of-inflation-in-earnings-in-the-week-ahead.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reporting earnings</a> this week: AT&T, P&G, Johnson & Johnson, Verizon, Intel, Coca-Cola, IBM, and Netflix. Big banks have set a high bar. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Earthy things: </strong>Earth Day is Thursday, and so is the release date of a new PBS documentary on activist Greta Thunberg. 4/20 is on...4/20 (Tuesday).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Everything else: </strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Today, closing arguments begin in the trial over the killing of George Floyd.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>On Thursday, SpaceX is planning to send four astronauts to the International Space Station.</span></li>
<li aria-level="1" style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Wait—the Oscars are on Sunday? </span></li>
</ul>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nECONOMY\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nSmall Businesses Shake It Off\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Small businesses in a row\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMTkyL3NtYWxsX2J1c2luZXNzZXNfaW5fYV9yb3cuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOne year ago, just weeks into lockdowns and stay-at-home orders, economists warned of the potential closures of millions of businesses across the country. But preliminary data from the first 12 months of the pandemic shows those predictions fell flatter than our bet on skinny jeans never going out of style. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFewer than 200,000 business establishments \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/covid-19s-toll-on-u-s-business-200-000-extra-closures-in-pandemics-first-year-11618580619?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eclosed\u003c/a\u003e from March 2020 to February 2021 on top of the roughly 600,000 businesses that typically turnover in a given year, according to a new Federal Reserve report. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eImportant distinction:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e An estimated 130,000 of those \"excess\" closures were businesses going under (as opposed to just closing one of their locations).\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eUnsurprisingly, personal services were the hardest hit—about half of the excess failures were businesses like barber shops and nail salons. But some categories, including carry-out restaurants, grocery stores, and outdoor recreation, saw fewer failures than a normal year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e 200,000 excess closures certainly had devastating consequences for owners and employees, but the unemployment impact was \u003ca href=\"https://www.reuters.com/business/pandemic-destroyed-fewer-us-firms-than-feared-fed-study-shows-2021-04-16/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eless than you might expect\u003c/a\u003e. Business exits are typically higher among firms with five or fewer workers, and the majority of the US' 26 million small businesses are sole proprietorships. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eBut this isn't over \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe full scope of business damage won't be known for years, and surveys continue to show many are still struggling under burdens of unpaid loans and back rent. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe impact of closures also hasn't been felt evenly, Fed surveys show. Firms owned by people of color \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/04/16/success/minority-owned-small-businesses-pandemic/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexperienced\u003c/a\u003e larger declines in sales and more difficulty accessing capital. If requests for pandemic aid were granted, they were less likely than white-owned businesses to get the amount requested. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Fed report offers an upbeat view of business resiliency during Covid and evidence that PPP and other aid programs prevented more permanent damage. \"Not only are things less bad than we thought, but they are less bad by an order of magnitude,\" MIT Sloan Prof. Scott Stern told the WSJ.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, a group of 12 elite European soccer clubs and Italy. The ultimate goal is to have 15 permanent teams in a \"closed\" structure more in line with US sports leagues.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eAnd what do they want? \u003c/strong\u003eMore money. Super League teams would get $400+ million each just for participating, a sum more than 4x what they'd earn from winning the current top European competition, the Champions League. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe response from existing soccer leadership: \u003c/strong\u003eImagine an announcer saying the word \"goooooal\" for 30 seconds, but replace that with \"nooooo.\" UEFA, European soccer's governing body and the organization that runs the Champions League, called it a \"cynical project,\" and even UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson and French President Emmanuel Macron denounced it. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ea battle royale for the soul of European width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe US and China don't agree on much—trade, aggressions in the South China Sea, where to set the thermostat. But in a \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/joe-biden-climate-shanghai-climate-change-john-kerry-905125d79b6c31940b8747df86c2a87a?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejoint statement\u003c/a\u003e Saturday, the world's two largest economies said they'd work together to combat climate change. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf you're looking for specifics, this is not the statement for you. But the countries did agree to take \"\u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/71f724ff-a25c-4ff7-8713-b0aa02d3adb5?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003econcrete actions\u003c/a\u003e\" this decade to reduce emissions in line with the goals of the Paris Agreement, which commits countries to limit warming to \"well below\" two degrees Celsius relative to the preindustrial era.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThat won't happen \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.axios.com/us-china-agree-joint-climate-action-838a35b5-92a8-47c6-901f-1a7e9926f5bc.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewithout buy-in\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e from the US and China. The countries are No. 1 and No. 2 on the World's Top Emitters list, together contributing almost half of the fossil fuel emissions that warm the planet. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eCompared to his predecessor, President Biden is taking a U-turn with an aggressive plan to tackle climate change. However, he has largely maintained the same antagonistic tone toward the Chinese government.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003elater this week, the US will announce new carbon emissions targets before hosting 40 world leaders at a virtual climate summit. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePeloton is in a war of words with US regulators over the safety of one of its core products.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eOn Saturday, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said customers of Peloton's Tread+ treadmill should \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/17/us-cpsc-tells-consumers-to-stop-using-pelotons-tread-treadmill.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enot use it\u003c/a\u003e around small children or pets because they could get trapped underneath the machine.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe agency cited \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-treadmills-unsafe-for-people-with-young-children-or-pets-federal-agency-says-11618680690?mod=hp_lead_pos5\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e39 incidents\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e involving the Tread+, including the death of a child that Peloton acknowledged last month. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt's not clear whether Peloton's treadmill is more dangerous than other treadmills.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe company \u003ca href=\"https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/peloton-refutes-consumer-product-safety-commission-claims-301270942.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epushed back\u003c/a\u003e against the report, calling it \"inaccurate and misleading.\" Peloton said there is \"no reason to stop using the Tread+, as long as all warnings and safety instructions are followed.\" \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003ePeloton's biggest problem last year was making enough equipment to fulfill elevated demand for its connected fitness products.
